turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi, hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi, can you hear me?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>, I can hear you well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi, my name is Doctor Gohil. I'm one of the doctors that works at Babylon.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can I, <UNIN/> can I check your name and date of birth, please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, hi doctor. My name is.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes my, my name is uh, Roberto Mendoza. <UNSURE>And</UNSURE>, uh, I'm, I was born on the first of January, of um, uh, nineteen ninety two.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and are you in a space that's quiet and you're able to talk?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh sorry, I um, of nineteen ninety, sorry I'm forty eight. Sorry, I forgot that <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, you're forty eight, and are you able to talk at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Tell me, uh, it says here you have a <UNIN/>, uh, you're having problems going to the toilet?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, so I have uh, I have um. I don't know how do you say it properly, in English. Uh, I mean <UNSURE>without sounding</UNSURE> good, like diarrhoea, for, for, yeah. So, it's lasting for like three days. And, uh, yeah, I, I don't know, uh, I don't know, what could cause it. I, uh, um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I have a bit of uh, <UNSURE>pain, abdominal</UNSURE> pain. And I, had a bit of vomiting.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And uh, uh, yeah. <UNSURE>So</UNSURE> this uh, kind of like uh, what is happening to me.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Tell me how you were three days ago, before this started.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you have any medical problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, so I have, I have, I have <UNSURE>a</UNSURE>, asthma, and I take some uh, some uh, <UNIN/> um, inhaler.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I don't know, <UNIN/> uh, I take an inhaler, um. <UNIN/> and um. <UNIN/> uh, I have an allergy. I have <UNSURE>N, N, NK</UNSURE>, NKDA allergy. So, I don't know if it's because, uh, I don't know. Could be the inhaler, or, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That's <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And apart from asthma, do you have anything else?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I don't maybe it's work, because you know it's, this thing here in the stomach <UNSURE>stuff</UNSURE>. I, I always have in the back of my head <UNSURE>and</UNSURE> my father. Because he died about um, ten years ago of <UNSURE>bowel</UNSURE> cancer.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yep</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, yeah, this is kind of <UNSURE>uh</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, my, my worries. I, I don't know <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, you've, you've had the diarrhoea for <UNIN/> three days, and now you're having <UNIN/> pain and vomiting.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, yes, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Was the diarrhoea been getting better or worse?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, uh, I <UNIN/>, I think it, it's not getting better or worse. It's kind of like uh, uh, like, <UNSURE>middle</UNSURE>, like normal, like uh, it, it, it hasn't gone away, it hasn't <UNSURE>worsened</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how often do you go to the toilet?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I go, I need to go, I, I can't go to work because I need to go like every. I don't <UNSURE>is</UNSURE> this feeling like I go to <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> toilet, and then when I finish, I need to, I feel I need to go again.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And, and uh, and, yeah. So, I need to be like close to the toilet uh, all the <UNSURE>time</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That must be, that must be hard.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, it's.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you had to drink more water than normal?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I don't know, maybe I'm not drinking enough water, <UNIN/> yeah. I drink uh, I think I, yeah I don't know. I, I think I don't drink enough water.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: An important question, have you noticed any blood?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no, I haven't noticed any, any <UNSURE>blood</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And you mentioned tummy pain, can you tell me more about your tummy pain, like where it is, and if it goes anywhere?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, <UNIN/>, the pain is mainly uh, focus in, in the centre area of the abdomen, like under the belly, under the belly button. And, uh, yeah, and sometimes I can hear my stomach, uh, like, <UNSURE>it comes</UNSURE>, uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. You've been able to eat and drink?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yes, but, yes but I, I go to the toilet <UNSURE>also</UNSURE> often. So I, I, I, yeah I try not to eat a lot because I, yeah I just, going to the toilet every, ten minute.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hmm. And you said the tummy pain's in the middle of your tummy. Does it go anywhere else?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no, just there, and it, it seems to be <UNSURE>alleviate</UNSURE> a bit, toilet, and maybe it's like trapped gas. So, I don't know what it is, but.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And when was the last time you vomited?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I think it was this morning. This morning, I, but <UNSURE>the, the</UNSURE> thing is like, because I'm not eating anything now. So, I, I haven't vomited again.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you have any breakfast?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Right, I don't know.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I didn't. Uh, no sorry, yes I did actually, I did. Pardon, I had some fruit, I had some fruit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And <UNIN/>, and you vomited that up, afterwards?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And afterwards, I didn't have anything, then I got a bit of nausea, and I vomited, and then, <UNIN/> uh, yeah and that was it, and that was it. And I <UNSURE>have any</UNSURE> <UNIN/> today, and so now I'm, uh, I think I'm OK, but uh, yeah, and I don't, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Did you notice any blood when you vomit?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hmm. I think I do, I think I do, but is uh, uh, no, no actually I can't say sorry, I'm sorry. I, I, I don't think there is blood because uh, yeah it was, it was the strawberries that I was having for breakfast. So, so, yeah, it wasn't blood.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, um, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> did you eat anything that you think might of been bad, or anything that could have caused the tummy pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I, I don't know. To be honest, sometimes I have, when I get a bit of anxiety, I, I use my inhaler. And, but my inhaler kind of um, run out <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> one. Because you know, I'm a foreigner, so I have uh, this brand, but I bought a new one here.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>. OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And, uh, I don't know maybe this new one has cause it, <UNSURE>this</UNSURE>, this problem. I don't know.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. It's very unlikely for an inhaler to cause tummy pain, like this. Normally, it's when you eat, um, bad food or food that has gone off, and you normally get symptoms like you have suggested. But just <UNSURE>to </UNSURE> double-check, have you noticed any problems with your breathing?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Mmm</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, uh, <UNIN/> I, I always have problems with my breathing, because of the asthma like, <UNIN/>. When I, <UNIN/>, I need to use my inhaler a little bit, but apart of the normal, I haven't, I haven't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how about chest, have you noticed any chest pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>, no, I haven't <UNIN/>, I haven't noticed any chest pain.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how about, um, walking and talking, are those all both OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, walking and talking, uh, yes, yes. Uh, I, I, but uh, but yeah I don't walk very far because uh, I, yeah I need to, I need to go to the toilet now and then. So, I'm spending some time at <UNSURE>home</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yep. And when you press on your tummy, does it cause any pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh, it does a little bit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sorry, I was just writing some things down.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, what it sounds like to me is that you might have eaten something bad, and it's causing your tummy pain. And it's <UNIN/>, this is normally called gastroenteritis, so, an infection of the tummy.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Normally, when patients have this <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> do some things. Number one is to drink lots of water and fluids, because you're losing lots at the moment. Number two is to make sure and look out for any fevers, so, if you start getting a temperature then you need <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Mmm, OK</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And <UNSURE>please</UNSURE> stay home for the time being until you get slightly better.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. OK, I, <UNSURE>yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And normally,

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Normally, things like antibiotics don't help, they make the situation worse.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. I didn't, yeah, sorry I <UNSURE>didn't</UNSURE>. No, I was saying I didn't have any, fever recently. I, I was sweating a little bit <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> last four days, but I, I. Not sure if, if I had bit of fever, but very, little <UNSURE>or, or, I'm, I'm</UNSURE> but I don't think so, I don't think. I don't know maybe.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, that's.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, I think that's what we should do for the time being, if you feel you're getting much worse, than I would suggest you go and see your GP in real, in real life, in person, so they <UNSURE>can loot at</UNSURE> your belly.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, I will, yeah I will book then, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> book <UNIN/>, I will wait a couple of days to see, or one more day, and then I will book, and then, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Great! Cool! Do you have any more questions for me?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, <UNIN/>, no, that's uh, that's it. I was maybe just concerned about my father's <UNIN/> uh, <UNIN/> medical history, that would uh, I could <UNSURE>be</UNSURE> at some kind of risk.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, the, the things that you've told me are most suggestive of an infection of your tummy and less likely to be something your father had, but if your things don't get worse, then that's something that we can look up from the GP.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>. Yeah, that sounds good, that sounds good. OK. Thank you very much doctor, for your time. Bye <UNSURE>bye</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Does that sound OK?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Thank you <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Bye bye.
